abstract.p: Repr Rick Boucher, declaring that letter of US copyright law should not limit use of new technology that remains true to its spirit, introduces bill that would legalize controversial MyMP3.com music service; action on legislation is not expected before end of current session of Congress, and Boucher will reintroduce it next session; photo (S)

block.p: Declaring that the letter of United States copyright law should not limit the use of new technology that remains true to its spirit, Representative Rick Boucher, a Virginia Democrat, has introduced a bill that would legalize the controversial MyMP3.com service. Earlier this year, a federal judge ruled that the service infringed the copyrights of the major recording labels. But Mr. Boucher said MyMP3.com, which enables consumers to listen to CD's by logging on to the MP3.com site, was analogous to consumers carrying CD's with them without the inconvenience of doing so. Action on the legislation is not expected before the end of the current session of Congress, but Mr. Boucher said it would be reintroduced in the next session. Trade groups representing the music industry circulated a letter among members of Congress on Monday calling the legislation misguided.
